FacilityName: Tesoro Logistics Operations, LLC - Pasco Terminal

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Tesoro Logistics Operations, LLC (Tesoro) - Pasco is a petroleum terminal and pipeline facility distributing product throughout the northwest United States including various grades of refined liquids and gasses. The RMP regulated process is limited to the on-site Butane gasoline loading rack and tank batch blending process consisting of one pressure vessel, an offload station (truck), pump, piping and associated appurtenances. 

The Pasco Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining the Butane Blending process in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Tesoro believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand-in-hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance. 

The Pasco Terminal Butane Blending process is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. Tesoro promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Tesoro and the Pasco Terminal have designed and implemented, including: 

A. A description of the facility/stationary source and its use of regulated substances (n-Butane); B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs (Program Level 3); 
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals; 
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and 
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety. 

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

The Butane Blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances in excess of their respective threshold quantities are identified. By virtue of the flam

mable effects associated with Butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions while handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, reduce the threat to employee health, and minimize potential impacts to nearby members of the community. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which Butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process.  Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the Pasco Terminal's safety policies and procedures. 

The facility maintains fixed inventories of Butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) approximate 60,000-gallon (water capacity) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied Butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The Butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into rack gasoline fill lines or batch blended into gasoline tank receipts. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, fusible/low-melting point element 
(<250 degrees Fahrenheit) feeds to pneumatic valves (designed to fail-safe), automatic fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, pipe thermal/hydrostatic pressure reliefs, and various pressure/temperature/flow related alarms. Access to the Pasco Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and approved contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

The Pasco Terminal's accidental release prevention and emergency planning/ response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the regulated substances to facility employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard
29CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the facility:

1) Employee Participation

ntities; 
-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks; 
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release and disable the process; and 
-Fire/cooling water conveyance systems to facilitate external fire response operations. 

General Emergency Response 

-Emergency alert systems; 
-Periodic emergency training for employees; 
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; 
-Emergency training/exercises with facility personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies; -
Mutual Aid with Local Fire Departments; and 
-Participation with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) or equivalent. 

The Pasco Terminal Butane Blending process was designed and constructed following the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58 [2024 at the time of construction]) requirements for LPG storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate release prevention controls, an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) is in place for the Facility with response activities being coordinated with the City of Pasco Fire Department and Franklin County Emergency Management. 

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

The Pasco Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal maintains records for all accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. As this is a new process, there have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials defined under the EPA RMP Rule. 

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

The Pasco Terminal is identified as a Non-Responding Stationary Source and, as such, utilizes outside sources (City of Pasco Fire Department) for offensive-type response actions. 

In the event of an emergency involving the Butane Blending process, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the City of Pasco Fire Department to request their assistance

. The Facility personnel maintain incipient fire and 1st Responder-Operations capabilities. The City of Pasco Fire Department and Franklin County Emergency Management have received response training prior to startup. In addition to startup training,  both agencies participate in annual training/coordination/notification events and are contacted about potential table-top and/or full-scale exercises. 

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Tesoro is continually striving to make the Pasco Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.  In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Tesoro looks for, and actively seeks employee input, on process safety improvements per its Employee Participation program. All process safety events (as defined in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed and/or investigated via root-cause analysis (ex. TapRooT) per corporate policy. Additionally, the Pasco Terminal works cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.
